prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection of the molecular outflow in IRAS 13120-5453
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Deep observation of the CO(1-0) line. The goal is to detect the molecular outflow in the galaxy in the form of broad wings in the line profile.
The CN(1-0) transitions at nu_rest = 113.17GHz and 113.49GHz are observed in one of the free basebands.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We used a channel width of 100km/s for the sensitivity calculations. This is based on our main goal of detecting the weak and broad CO(1-0) outflow emission.
However, together with the outflow emission, we will get the core CO(1-0) disk emission and other molecular lines in parallel basebands which are considerably narrower (~300km/s). We might also find molecular absorption features in the line profiles with typical velocity widths <~100km/s. For those reasons we request a minimum spectral resolution of 5km/s.
The total outflow emission can cover more than 2000km/s (see fig.2c). In order to detect all the emission and also have some emission free regions, we request a total window width ~5000km/s.

The CO(1-0) spatial distribution of this source is not known (only single beam observations are available), but it's expected to be of the order of 2.5kpc (~4 arcsec), based on the CO(1-0) maps of other galaxies with similar properties (ULIRGs, see for example Downes & Solomon 1998 and Cicone et al. 2014).
We request an angular resolution of 0.5arsec (~0.3kpc) in order to be able to resolve the CO emission and still recover most of the extended emission. For this angular resolution we do not expect any beam dilution (per velocity channel).

The goal is to detect the galaxy molecular outflow in the form of broad, high-velocity CO(1-0) wings superimposed on the galaxy disk core CO emission (see fig.2c). The outflow emission is much weaker than the disk emission, but covers a different velocity range, so they can be separated (see for example Cicone et al. 2014).
We use the OH 119micron absorption line to estimate the total amount of molecular gas involved in the outflow. For that we assumed that the outflow CO(1-0) emission is proportional to the OH119 equivalent width corrected by the square of the luminosity distance. This relation has been calibrated with the 3 galaxies for which we already have CO(1-0) and OH119 observations: Mrk 231, IRAS 08572 and IRAS 10565. The scatter in this relation is quite low (~30%).
The requested rms is based on the predicted CO(1-0) peak emission in each of the red and blue outflow components, assuming a velocity width of 500km/s. In order to optimize the integration time we used a channel width of 100km/s for the sensitivity calculation.
We request a 10sigma detection of the outflow peak emission with a 100km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the outflow in several spectral pixels with a S/N > 5.

The CO(1-0) spatial distribution of this source is not known (only single beam observations are available), but it's expected to be of the order of 2.5kpc (~2 arcsec), based on the CO(1-0) maps of other galaxies with similar properties (ULIRGs, see for example Downes & Solomon 1998 and Cicone et al. 2014).
We request an angular resolution of 0.3 arsec (~0.3kpc) in order to be able to resolve the CO emission and still recover most of the extended emission. For this angular resolution we do not expect any beam dilution (per velocity channel).

The goal is to detect the galaxy molecular outflow in the form of broad, high-velocity CO(1-0) wings superimposed on the galaxy disk core CO emission (see fig.2c). prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection of the molecular outflow in IRAS F05189-2524
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Deep observation of the CO(1-0) line. The goal is to detect the molecular outflow in the galaxy in the form of broad wings in the line profile.
The CN(1-0) transitions at nu_rest = 113.17GHz and 113.49GHz are observed in one of the free basebands.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We used a channel width of 100km/s for the sensitivity calculations. This is based on our main goal of detecting the weak and broad CO(1-0) outflow emission.
However, together with the outflow emission, we will get the core CO(1-0) disk emission and other molecular lines in parallel basebands which are considerably narrower (~300km/s). We might also find molecular absorption features in the line profiles with typical velocity widths <~100km/s. For those reasons we request a minimum spectral resolution of 5km/s.
The total outflow emission can cover more than 2000km/s (see fig.2c). In order to detect all the emission and also have some emission free regions, we request a total window width ~5000km/s.

The CO(1-0) spatial distribution of this source is not known (only single beam observations are available), but it's expected to be of the order of 2.5kpc (~3 arcsec), based on the CO(1-0) maps of other galaxies with similar properties (ULIRGs, see for example Downes & Solomon 1998 and Cicone et al. 2014).
We request an angular resolution of 0.4 arsec (~0.3kpc) in order to be able to resolve the CO emission and still recover most of the extended emission. For this angular resolution we do not expect any beam dilution (per velocity channel).

The goal is to detect the galaxy molecular outflow in the form of broad, high-velocity CO(1-0) wings superimposed on the galaxy disk core CO emission (see fig.2c). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In the last few years massive molecular outflows have been found in a number of nearby active galaxies, initiated by pioneering Herschel and mm-interferometry projects performed by our team and others. These outflows may represent the long sought evidence for the strong QSO mode feedback onto the host galaxy, required by galaxy evolution models. Here we propose to use ALMA to study molecular outflows in 3 targets, for which the presence of such outflows have been proven by our Herschel OH observations, by detecting and resolving the associated broad wings in CO(1-0). These observations will reveal the structure of the outflow (size, distribution, anisotropies) and therefore help to better constrain key parameters of the outflow, such as scale size, mass loss rates, energetics, and driving mechanism. They will also be extremely useful for the interpretation of future ALMA outflow observations in CO and OH in the high redshift Universe. This is a re-submission, slightly modified, of a Cycle 1 Priority 1 proposal that was carried over into Cycle 2 but only partially observed at the time of the Cycle 3 submission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is a resubmission of 2012.1.00306.S Massive molecular outflows and negative feedback in active galaxies Eckhard Sturm
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
